prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: smg-group1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: group 1 targets from Bussmann et al: G09v1.124 G09v1.40 SDP17 SDP130

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Required sensitivity: We plan to observe our targets in band 6 at frequencies between 230 to 270 GHz. We aim to achieve 3 sigma optical depth limits of at least tau = 0.15 per 100 km/s. Given that the separate components in the images of the SMGs are expected to have integrated flux densities between 5.7 and 15.5 mJy, we need to reach a rms noise level of 0.27 mJy per 100 km/s, which should be reached in 25 minutes on source, under average weather conditions. For the brightest components, the 3sigma optical depth limits are 5%. In these cases, we will reach a tau=0.15 limit even for 10 km/s resolution elements. In terms of brightness temperature, our target rms noise level is 22 mK per 100 km/s.
Correlator setup: The high spectral resolution mode (FDM) will be used in dual polarization mode with a factor 16 binning, which gives us 7.8 MHz channels over 1.875 GHz bandwidth per baseband. The resulting velocity resolution is ∼10 km/s. This is much narrower than the expected width of the absorption lines, so additional off-line spectral smoothing will be required. However, the low resolution TDM mode results in a velocity resolution of ∼38 kms−1, which is at the risk of being too coarse to resolve velocity structure in the lines.
To reach maximum bandwidth, we choose to put three basebands in the USB. One is centered on the redhshifted frequency of the 12CH+(1-0) line and the other basebands are offset by 1.36 GHz, thus using the maximum IF bandwidth. This way, we reach the maximum achievable contiguous bandwidth in band 6, covering 5 GHz and a velocity range of ∼6000 km/s. The basebands are overlapping by 400 MHz, ensuring that we reach a constant noise level over the total 5 GHz. The total continuum sensitivity will be 34 μJy, corresponding to 0.7 mK.
Imaging requirements: The optimal spatial resolution for this project is 0.5 arcsec. With much lower resolution we will not be able to resolve the different parts of the lensed images that may provide information on the different size and shape of the absorbing gas compared to that of the SMG continuum dust emission (see science proposal). With higher spatial resolution we may overresolve the structure and lose flux.
A single pointing is requested. Standard calibration will be sufficient. Since we are looking for broad absorption lines, an accurate bandpass is required, but the standard ALMA goal of a S/N of 100 per channel is certainly sufficient for our goals.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: smg-group2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: group 2 targets from Bussmann et al: NAv1.144 NAv1.56

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Required sensitivity: We plan to observe our targets in band 6 at frequencies between 230 to 270 GHz. We aim to achieve 3 sigma optical depth limits of at least tau = 0.15 per 100 km/s. Given that the separate components in the images of the SMGs are expected to have integrated flux densities between 5.7 and 15.5 mJy, we need to reach a rms noise level of 0.27 mJy per 100 km/s, which should be reached in 25 minutes on source, under average weather conditions. For the brightest components, the 3sigma optical depth limits are 5%. In these cases, we will reach a tau=0.15 limit even for 10 km/s resolution elements. In terms of brightness temperature, our target rms noise level is 22 mK per 100 km/s.
Correlator setup: The high spectral resolution mode (FDM) will be used in dual polarization mode with a factor 16 binning, which gives us 7.8 MHz channels over 1.875 GHz bandwidth per baseband. The resulting velocity resolution is ∼10 km/s. This is much narrower than the expected width of the absorption lines, so additional off-line spectral smoothing will be required. However, the low resolution TDM mode results in a velocity resolution of ∼38 kms−1, which is at the risk of being too coarse to resolve velocity structure in the lines.
To reach maximum bandwidth, we choose to put three basebands in the USB. One is centered on the redhshifted frequency of the 12CH+(1-0) line and the other basebands are offset by 1.36 GHz, thus using the maximum IF bandwidth. This way, we reach the maximum achievable contiguous bandwidth in band 6, covering 5 GHz and a velocity range of ∼6000 km/s. The basebands are overlapping by 400 MHz, ensuring that we reach a constant noise level over the total 5 GHz. The total continuum sensitivity will be 34 μJy, corresponding to 0.7 mK.
Imaging requirements: The optimal spatial resolution for this project is 0.5 arcsec. With much lower resolution we will not be able to resolve the different parts of the lensed images that may provide information on the different size and shape of the absorbing gas compared to that of the SMG continuum dust emission (see science proposal). With higher spatial resolution we may overresolve the structure and lose flux.
A single pointing is requested. Standard calibration will be sufficient. Since we are looking for broad absorption lines, an accurate bandpass is required, but the standard ALMA goal of a S/N of 100 per channel is certainly sufficient for our goals.

Required sensitivity: We plan to observe the Eyelash in band 6 at frequencies between 251 GHz. We aim to achieve 3 sigma optical depth limits of at least tau = 0.15 per 100 km/s. Given that the separate components in the images of the Eyelash are expected to have integrated flux densities of ~3.9 mJy, we need to reach a rms noise level of 0.18 mJy per 100 km/s, which should be reached in 51 minutes on source, under average weather conditions. In terms of brightness temperature, our target rms noise level is 14 mK per 100 km/s.
Correlator setup: The high spectral resolution mode (FDM) will be used in dual polarization mode with a factor 16 binning, which gives us 7.8 MHz channels over 1.875 GHz bandwidth per baseband. The resulting velocity resolution is ∼10 km/s. This is much narrower than the expected width of the absorption lines, so additional off-line spectral smoothing will be required. However, the low resolution TDM mode results in a velocity resolution of ∼38 kms−1, which is at the risk of being too coarse to resolve velocity structure in the lines.
To reach maximum bandwidth, we choose to put three basebands in the USB. One is centered on the redhshifted frequency of the 12CH+(1-0) line and the other basebands are offset by 1.36 GHz, thus using the maximum IF bandwidth. This way, we reach the maximum achievable contiguous bandwidth in band 6, covering 5 GHz and a velocity range of ∼6000 km/s. The basebands are overlapping by 400 MHz, ensuring that we reach a constant noise level over the total 5 GHz. The total continuum sensitivity will be 34 μJy, corresponding to 0.7 mK.
Imaging requirements: The optimal spatial resolution for this project is 0.5 arcsec. With much lower resolution we will not be able to resolve the different components. The probability of hitting an opaque region is higher when the different clumps of background emission are resolved. With higher spatial resolution we may overresolve the structure.
A single pointing is requested. Standard calibration will be sufficient. Since we are looking for broad absorption lines, an accurate bandpass is required, but the standard ALMA goal of a S/N of 100 per channel is certainly sufficient for our goals.
For the Eyelash, the 870 μm SMA map of with 0.2 arcsec resolution recovers 82% of the total single dish flux. Therefore, with our resolution of 0.50 arcsec we expect to recover most of the continuum flux as well. We used the 870 μm SMA map as in input model in simobserve, scaling the flux so as to make it correspond to the published 1.2mm flux of 25.5 mJy. We then simulated a 1.0 hour observation with the C34-4 array at 251 GHz, using a total frequency width of 100 km/s. The cleaned image, shown in the Figure demonstrates that the flux will be resolved in about four components, three of which have total fluxes of ∼4 mJy and the most Northern one has ∼3 mJy.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The growth of galaxies in the Early universe is largely governed by the conversion of massive gas reservoirs into stars. The gas-feeding of star-forming galaxies generates intense turbulence that delays star-formation as long as it is not dissipated: turbulence acts as a mass and energy buffer over timescales that are essentially unknown. The unique chemical properties of CH+ make it a robust tracer of turbulent dissipation. The recent discovery of very bright lensed submillimeter galaxies (SMG) at high-z, combined with the outstanding sensitivity and resolution power of ALMA, opens, for the first time, the possibility of CH+(1-0) absorption spectroscopy against the continuum of 7 SMGs with star-formation rates (SFR) differing by a factor of 7: detections will give turbulent dissipation rates whose scaling with the SFRs will be searched. They will also allow to (1) distinguish infall and outflow from turbulence, (2) trace weakly molecular gas of low density, and (3) image the absorbing gas across the lensed images of the SMGs and along the four star-forming regions in the Eyelash galaxy.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory, Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics
Astronomy Department, Michigan at Ann Arbor, University of
